awd_titl_txt: FMitF: A Novel Framework for Learning Formal Abstractions and Causal Relations from Temporal Behaviors
awd_abstract_narration:
Formal methods consist of a collection of techniques that help developers rigorously reason about the behaviors of software and hardware systems with the help of mathematical logic. While formal logic has been used for articulating system specifications for the purpose of verification or software synthesis, this project introduces a logic-based framework to address machine-learning problems such as classification (which category should a new datum be put into?), clustering (how should a collection of data points be grouped together into categories?) and discovery of causal relations (when should an earlier data observation be deemed to cause the appearance of a later data observation?) for time-series data, in which repeated observations are made over time. The use of formal logic opens new avenues such as enhancing the interpretability of machine-learning models, the explainability of learning results, and articulation of formal guarantees on the behavior of learning algorithms. The societal impact of this work targets discovery of latent information in time-series data in diverse domains such as healthcare, autonomous systems, and security. The research impacts education by providing cross-disciplinary training of undergraduate and graduates students in areas of data science, machine learning, formal methods, and introducing students to methods from statistical physics on a number of real-world systems.

This project explores the intersection between the logical inference based on real-time temporal logics and statistical inference prevalent in machine learning. The algorithms developed in this project allow users to express domain knowledge in the form of signal predicates or chance constraints, and output the results of classification, clustering or causal discovery as formulas in specific real-time temporal logics. This allows the results of the machine-learning algorithms to be human-interpretable, and also improves the explainability of learning algorithms by answering the question of why a particular time-series datum is classified or clustered in a specific fashion.  These techniques are able to model uncertainty in time-series data by creating a new class of non-parametric learning methods that combine concepts from statistical physics, information theory, and statistical inference. The use of a logic-based framework allows providing formal guarantees on the learning process itself by applying ideas such as probably-approximately-correct learning (from computational learning theory) to the inference of real-time temporal logic formulas from data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Time-series data or signals are data where the constituent elements of the data are presented as ordered and time-stamped sequences. Such data is everywhere: econometrics, physiological signals, sensors and actuators of cyber-physical systems, disease spread, and so on.  Techniques ranging from statistical time-series analysis to modern machine learning approaches have been used to analyze such data.  Analyzing such data often encounters problems for classification, clustering, or forecasting from such data; however, modern techniques relying on deep neural networks often lack explainability.  Temporal logic, an important contribution from formal methods, has been used for almost 50 years to reason rigorously reason about the temporal behaviors of various systems. In contrast to many learning-based methods, logic-based formalisms help express temporal properties of system behaviors in a mathematically precise fashion without losing their explanatory ability. In this project, we explored three different thrusts: (1) using temporal logic to perform machine learning tasks, (2) tackling learning and control when there is uncertainty in data, and (3) applying formal methods to problems such as causal inference and novel machine learning applications.

In thrust1, we focused on learning logical formulas from time-series data. We focused on Signal Temporal Logic (STL) - a formalism that allows expressing logical and temporal properties of data. In supervised learning settings, we we were able to learn STL classifiers with reasonable level of accuracy without relying on any a priori knowledge about the structure of the formula. We also extended this approach to mine STL-based environment assumptions by a similar approach.  Though STL is expressive it is cumbersome to express shape properties; to address this, we developed the language of shape expressions -- these are regular expressions where atomic predicates are shapes (lines, exponential curves, sinusoids, etc.). We developed algorithms for pattern matching and mining such shape expressions. Our work on this topic published in the Runtime Verification 2019 conference won the Best Paper Award. We were able to learn a shape expression that can characterize a specific kind of heart condition that can be seen through EKG data, and developed a new tool called ShapeIt which has been used for testing cyber-physical systems.

In thrust2, we investigated the problem of learning and control from Stochastic STL (StSTL) specifications which are evaluated on stochastic processes. We formulated algorithms for mining parameters and control synthesis for StSTL. Our follow-up work was on learning from demonstrations under StSTL constraints, which enabled applying reinforcement learning to learn control policies to respect such constraints.

In thrust3, we focused on using of temporal logic in machine learning. We investigated using logic-based regularizers for predictive algorithms such as LSTMs. While this project did not yield positive results, it opened avenues for purusing work such as VigDet; here we can encode temporal logic and other forms of prior knowledge as graphs and apply an algorithm to learn a deep learning model from both data and prior knowledge. We applied this to problems of coordination detection in social media applications. We used our previously designed techniques for learning STL to learning Spatio-Temporal Logic formulas to explain spatio-temporal phenomena that arise in epidemiology or smart cities.  Another interesting result was a human-centered approach for detecting forgery in face images, leveraging recent advances in deep learning, and symbolic reasoning to combat deepfakes. We learned temporal inconsistencies from deepfakes, as both a form of visual explanations and a vehicle to systematically verify temporal logic specifications within the model.

In addition to the work focused on the primary objectives of this proposal, the synergy between formal methods and machine learning researchers led to investigations into formalizing trustworthiness for deep neural network-based classifiers and multi-agent transportation systems. We also investigated problems in fractal geometry and time-varying complex networks. Some of our work was published in journals and conference proceedings including Scientific Reports, NeurIPS, ICLR, and IEEE Trans. on Dependable and Secure Computing.

The broader impact of our project is on the greater penetration of formal methods tools such as temporal logic into traditional time-series learning and machine learning domains. Through our work on learning from demonstrations using temporal logic, applied to the robotics domain (published in Robotics Automation and Letters), we were able to show that additional structure obtained through temporal logic formulas can significantly reduce the time required for machine learning algorithms to converge. In the other direction, interaction with machine learning researchers has brought a data-driven sensibility to our work in formal methods. For example, we worked on a paper to translate natural language specifications to robot task descriptions in STL (published as part of a series on Bridging the Gap between AI and Reality).  Several of our research results have been incorporated into courses at USC. The project supported Ph.D. work by several students in exciting topics at the intersection of formal methods, control theory, and machine learning.
